answers.answer: I do NOT recommend routinely getting heart catheterization "just to see" if there are progressive blockages... unless you have new CARDIAC symptoms such as pain, shortness of breath or passing out due to arrythmia.I DO think there are several to-dos here, and you might have gone through some of these already, but there they are:First, we need to define how much cardiac symptoms you currently experience and how your quality of life is. Are your limited by symptoms of chest pain with little exertion? Are you going to the hospital frequently due to congestive heart failure? Look up the NYHA class for heart failure and the CCS angina grades for YOU.Secondly, we should define how much of your heart is SCAR from coronary artery blockages, how much is HIBERNATING (alive but not contracting), how much is ISCHEMIC (alive, contrating, but frequently deprived of blood supply due to narrowing arteries), and how much is normal.  I would discuss with your doctor a CARDIAC PET STRESS + VIABILITY  test, which would lay out the above four categories in %.  This gives you and your cardiologist an idea of how much muscle is gone and never coming back (SCAR), and how much we have to save by performing a revascularization procedure (repeat CABG or a stent).Third, you might need to discuss the need for a defibrillator (ICD) to prevent sudden arrythmia due to muscle scars.  We recommend this for anyone with heart function (LVEF) < 35% (you mentioned yours is 30-40%?).  Sometimes your EKG might suggest that you would benefit from a fancier type of ICD (called CRT-D or "three lead" defibrillatro/pacer) which could help improve the mechanics of your heart pumping.Lastly and most importantly, you need to have a strict regimen of low cholesterol diet, blood pressure lowering medications (sounds like you are already taking, good!), and monitor for diabetes.  Your cholesterol profile needs to be maximally improved with statin medications and diet, if not already.This is a lot of information, and I am still quite unfamiliar with your situation (how many of these 10 cath's resulted in stents? if any? also when mammary arteries fail it typically means the original artery is actually OPEN -- this is the case?).  If you are unclear about these, or feel that your cardiologist is unable to provide these information, I recommend taking a  "health inventory" and get a second opinion at a larger cardiac institution.Good Luck!

Based on what you added, I do NOT recommend another cath, when the previous 10! did not find stentable areas.  You need to get to a cardiologist who will address the smoking, and the lack of medications such as an ACE inhibitor, which is indicated in someone with your heart function.
